Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2009 04:17PM ajlive wrote: Hello all.  I had an hysterectomy 18 years ago leaving an ovary.  I just got Estradiol test results back that showed post menopausal woman should have a level 27.  My level was 47 which meant my ovary is still building estrogen.  I have been on Femara for 5-months and was told to immediately quit taking the Femara because it would not work form.  Med Onc wants to put me on Tamoxifen now.  Do not want to do it.  I prefer to stay on Femara (was not having to much trouble with SE's).  I asked about having ovary removed and was told to get with my gynecologist.  Was also told that most insurance will not pay for this.  What?  If you are ER/PR+ I would think reducing the estrogen level will be preventative or recurrence of cancer since you are now at higher risk of getting other cancers. Thanks for starting this forum it has helped me make my decision to have ovary removed even if the insurance doesn't pay for it and with all the BC expense I can't really afford it.

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2009 08:35PM ajlive wrote: I finished radiation treatment 2-weeks ago.  The simulation on a CT-Scan normally does not take long.  For those that had mastectomies or the cancer was closer to the breast wall there is different setups they have to do so it takes longer due to having to make molds. It is a bit uncomfortable to hold your arm above your head holding on to the bar but it is doable.  Once you start taking the treatments it only takes about 10 minutes for setup and treatment. Make sure when you go for your simulation that you wear clothes you don't mind getting stained with their permanent markers.  They mark you up pretty good while lining you up.  The markers gets all over your bra and clothing.  Also, get you some sports bras or bras with no under wires to wear while having the radiation treatments.  Your skin will begin to get sensitive so you do not want to have a tight fitting bra. Get 100% aloe vera gel.  I started using it a couple of weeks before I had radiation treatment to get my skin prepared.  They toughest part is the last couple of weeks.  Take good care of your skin and drink lots of water.

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2009 02:51AM ajlive wrote: I had a lumpectomy in April of this year.  While still in the operating room the pathologist ran test and called back to the operating room to have another margin taken.  Second margin came out clear.  I was so happy they tested while still in the operating room.  I have heard of many that have had to go back for surgery due to cancer being to close to the margins.  They want to get clean margins.  Sorry you have to go back for surgery again.
